entry.title: [Fast Pair][Software Scanning] HardwareOffloadingSupportedProvider
entry.content:
Create the HardwareOffloadingSupportedProvider class. This provider

retrieves a pointer to an adapter object and determines whether

the device supports offloading bluetooth scanning onto its hardware.



Note that the HardwareOffloadingSupportedProvider ctor assumes that

it will receive an adapter object from BluetoothAdapterFactory::Get().

Comments above this function note that it will not return without an

initialized adapter object; for this reason, the circumstance where

the received pointer to the adapter is null is not tested, though

the pointer's validity is still tested before accessing member functions

in the HardwareOffloadingSupportedProvider.



The FakeBluetoothAdapter class is changed to better mock the

BluetoothAdapter class: on a change to status as 'present', it

notifies its observer of this change. A redundant function,

NotifyPoweredChanged, is deleted as well.



this, pass.



Tested: all unit tests in ash_unittests, including those written in

Fixed: b/322223967

entry.title: Fix race condition in MakeIterable()
entry.content:
Basically, you can iterate through the objects in persistent memory.

The function to make an object iterable (MakeIterable()) has an early

exit case if the object is already iterable. But it's racy if two

threads are trying to make the same object iterable.



In particular, the current code looks like:

```

if (block->next.load(std::memory_order_acquire) != 0)

return; // Already iterable.

block->next.store(kReferenceQueue, std::memory_order_release);

```



If block->next is 0, that means it was not made iterable yet. To

indicate that we are making it iterable, we set block->next to

kReferenceQueue which is a "dummy value" representing the end of the

linkedlist queue of iterable objects. However, doing so might

overwrite the work that another thread did, basically cutting the

linkedlist early, and some objects that were iterable are now "lost".



For example, let's say a thread is making object "A" iterable, but

context switches after the if check.

Then, another thread makes A iterable, and also makes some other

objects iterable. I.e., the linkedlist will look like:

head -> A -> B -> C -> kReferenceQueue (null).

Now, after the first thread resumes and completes, the queue will look

like:

head -> A -> kReferenceQueue (null) B -> C -> kReferenceQueue (null).

Note that objects B and C are not part of the linkedlist anymore.



Demo of the race condition:

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5237775



This fixes it by doing the whole thing in one operation instead

(compare-and-swap).



Found this while investigating the various NOTREACHED() in persistent

memory code. The window for this race condition is quite small, and I

doubt it happens in prod (it requires two different threads trying to

make the same object iterable, which I don't think happens, but I

haven't looked in-depth). So I don't think it's related to the

various NOTREACHED()s.



Bug: 1432981

Change-Id: Ibfa38970371b3d10755d6d2256c2bfe733de3013

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5238211

Reviewed-by: Alexei Svitkine

Commit-Queue: Luc Nguyen

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1252846}

> Update EG test util for non-disappearing snackbars

> MDCSnackBar recently changed behavior: in the past, all snackbars

entry.title: Clean up the shopping collection flag post desktop launch

There are two issues fixed here. The first is what when the omnibox

is focused in incognito mode, the color used was never updated for

the modernize visual update change. A new color was simply added.

be wired up to subscribe to the right thing.

entry.title: [Build] Fix build with use_sysroot=false
entry.content:
In [1], I changed system headers to use -I instead of -isystem

so that deps files would be generated for system headers. This was

required since the build uses -MMD. Without the deps files, updates

to system headers won't trigger a rebuild.



However, this was the incorrect solution since we still want to use

-isystem to avoid custom Chromium checks (like no raw pointers in

structs) for system headers. This CL switches back to -isystem in

all cases, and uses -MD instead of -MMD which will generate deps

files for system headers as well.



[1] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/1159689



R=thestig



Change-Id: If1197a67b5300dc8e41cb950fe779a1cc0c79da1

entry.title: [Android TRM] Add suggestions computation pipeline.
entry.content:
This CL integrates various Tab Resumption Module parts to establish the

pipeline to fetch and compute suggestions.

* New properties:

* Below are injected from mayCreateTabResumptionModuleCoordinator(),

and are fixed throughout the lifetime of the TRM:

* DATA_PROVIDER: TabResumptionDataProvider instance

* URL_IMAGE_PROVIDER: UrlImageProvider instance.

* CLICK_CALLBACK: Handler for tile click, set to open new tabs.

* SUGGESTION_BUNDLE: Computed SuggestionBundle instance, cached to

enable restoration for future RecyclerView usage.

* Setting this triggers render (implemented in follow-up CLs), which

also affects IS_VISIBLE (null -> hide the TRM).

* Mediator:

* Add getCurrentTimeMs(): Using method to testing override.

* Add isSuggestionValid(): Filters suggestion, currently only rejects

those with empty titles, but extendable for URL-based filtering.

* Add makeSuggestionBundle(): Takes ranked suggestion, applies filter,

limit to MAX_TILES_NUMBER = 2 suggestions, returns SuggestionBundle.

* Add reload() (formerly start()): Fetch data, make SuggestionBundle,

writes SUGGESTION_BUNDLE property.

* Coordinator:

* Add to own (data and image) provider instances, injected from CTOR.

* Binds data provider to call reload() on status change, so that the

TRM hides if user logs out or disables sync.

* Wraps suggestion click callback (preparing for metric injection),

passed to Mediator.

* Note: reload() is not called from CTOR, so the unit test can

instantiate the Coordinator in setUp(), do per-test initialization,

then call reload() to trigger flow.

* TabResumptionModuleUtils.mayCreateTabResumptionModuleCoordinator():

* Passed to new Coordinator to own:

* New ForeignSessionTabResumptionDataProvider, subject to change

once we also consider local tabs.

* New UrlImageProvider.

* Explicitly call Coordinator reload() to initialize.

* Add TODOs to metrics tracking code sites.



Also populate TabResumptionModuleMediatorUnitTest with 4 tests.

* The Mediator is not even stored as a variable; the test instantiates

Coordinator directly. However, the test refers to Mediator since the

emphasis is on the pre-View business logic.



Bug: 1515325

entry.title: [AsyncSB] Fix HPRT IsShowingInterstitial test flakes for async checks
entry.content:
The SafeBrowsingBlockingPageHashRealTimeCheckTest tests were previously

parametrized to run both async checks enabled and disabled. However,

that caused flaky failures when the async check had not finished by the

time the page loaded.



This CL re-parametrizes these test cases and also modifies the tests so

that they wait for any pending async checks to complete.



The TriggerHitReportAndClientSafeBrowsingReportRequest still only runs

for the async checks disabled case because it has other flaky failures

that will be addressed in a separate CL.

entry.title: Rename {absl => std}::optional in //components/
entry.content:
#cleanup



Automated patch. This is a no-op. Please avoid, to assign unrelated

bugs to this, as much as possible.



Context:

https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/cxx/c/nBD_1LaanTc/m/ghh-ZZhWAwAJ?utm_medium=email



As of https://crrev.com/1204351, absl::optional is now a type alias

for std::optional. We should migrate toward it.



Script:

```

function replace {

echo "Replacing $1 by $2"

git grep -l "$1" \

| cut -f1 -d: \

| grep \

-e "^components/" \

| grep \

-e "\.h" \

-e "\.cc" \

-e "\.mm" \

| grep -v \

-e "components/cast_streaming/browser/public/receiver_config.*" \

-e "components/power_metrics/*" \

-e "components/zucchini/patch_reader.*" \

| sort \

| uniq \

| xargs sed -i "s/$1/$2/g"

}

replace "absl::make_optional" "std::make_optional"

replace "absl::optional" "std::optional"

replace "absl::nullopt" "std::nullopt"

replace "absl::in_place" "std::in_place"

replace "absl::in_place_t" "std::in_place_t"

replace "\"third_party\/abseil-cpp\/absl\/types\/optional.h\"" ""



echo "Formatting:"



echo "IncludeBlocks: Regroup" >> ".clang-format"

echo "IncludeIsMainRegex: \"(_(android|apple|chromeos|freebsd|fuchsia|fuzzer|ios|linux|mac|nacl|openbsd|posix|stubs?|win))?(_(unit|browser|perf)?tests?)?$\"" >> ".clang-format"

git cl format

git restore ".clang-format"



git cl format

```



Bug: chromium:1500249

Change-Id: I34b45aba082a627d94fd9d3f9f994a60c64b40b1

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5200092

Auto-Submit: Arthur Sonzogni

Reviewed-by: danakj

Commit-Queue: danakj

Owners-Override: danakj

entry.title: [import-attributes] Only run WPT tests relying on `with` in the attributes virtual suite
entry.content:
Multiple WPT tests related to JSON and CSS modules are failing because

they rely on the `with` import attributes syntax, which is currently

disabled by default.



This patch marks them to only be run as part of the

`import-attributes-json-css-modules` virtual test suite, which enables

the `--harmony-import-attributes` flag, so that unflagging the syntax in

V8 (done in Ifc5af7f33aabfa0a2d5cd6c8381561848adbe392, blocked on this

patch) will not cause the tests to suddenly pass breaking the current

test expectations.



Note that for all the tests in

`wpt/html/semantics/scripting-1/the-script-element/css-module` and in

`wpt/html/semantics/scripting-1/the-script-element/json-module` there

are equivalent tests in the `css-module-assertions` and

`json-module-assertions` folders, using the `assert` syntax which is

currently enabled by default. The new expected failures for these tests

in the virtual test suite match the expected failures for the

`assert`-based tests.



Bug: v8:13856

entry.title: partition_alloc: Help developers understand UAFs.
entry.content:
Several developers independently asked why they were getting check:

PA_BASE_CHECK(IsPointeeAlive(address));



This means we detected a UAF:

entry.title: [infa] Add a node type for target mappings.
entry.content:
The _TARGET_BINARY node type currently represents 2 things: an entry to

be generated in gn_isolate_map.pyl and a valid reference that can be set

as the binary argument for gtests and isolated script tests. However,

not all such references actually make sense since a "binary" with type

"additional_compile_target" can't be used as the binary for a test. This

separates the 2 responsibilities into separate node types so that the

compatibility is enforced by the existence of nodes rather than

requiring additional code to check.



Bug: 1420012

Change-Id: I6db17d4078f90b362f1f4cf9ca65a20cb425840c

entry.title: [omnibox][grouping] Fixes DCHECK when verifying SideType of Groups in Sections.
entry.content:
A Section verifies at construction time whether the `Group`s in it have

the same SideType (Primary/Secondary) as well as the `GroupId`s in a

given `Group` have the same RenderType (Horizontal/Vertical).



It is possible that Chrome may allow a Secondary SideType `GroupId` that

the server does not always provide in its response. This can result in

a DCHECK because the default instance of omnibox::GroupConfig returned

from looking up omnibox::GroupConfigMap will have the default Primary

SideType. This is fixed by skipping `GroupId`s that are not present in

omnibox::GroupConfigMap when performing that check.



Perhaps these checks can be improved in the future by making sure a

`Section` only permits matches of the expected SideType and a `Group`

only permits matches of the expected RenderType.



This CL also makes some cosmetic changes to make the tests more readable.



Bug: 1343512

Change-Id: I8d13ab004fb63c01555b21826eccac883762c7e9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5239312

entry.title: [wpt] Don't construct unnecessary promises in `open-close.https.html`
entry.content:
When testing `MIDIInput.{open,close}`, `portPromise` and `accessPromise`

in `checkStateTransition()` are still constructed but not awaited.

Because `open-close.https.html` doesn't pass `access`, the latter is an

unhandled rejection that `chromedriver` detects when running the test

against `chrome` (`content_shell` seems to pass the test anyway).



Only construct the promises if needed. Also, machine-check a

precondition.



Bug: 1499775

entry.title: [anchor-position] Implements resolving anchor-center.
entry.content:
This patch implements the layout-time anchor-center logic.

In part based on:

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4919956



This patch:

1) Pulls the alignment logic out into its own struct, and step.

See: ComputeAlignment()

2) Adds a step for computing the anchor-center position if necessary.

See: ComputeAnchorCenterPosition()

3) Adjusts the logic in ComputeOutOfFlowInsets() to coerce any auto

insets to zero if anchor-center is present.

4) Adds special logic in ComputeInsetModifiedContainingBlock() to

coerce the available-size in a similar manner to center static

position.

entry.title: Address Media Foundation Content Playing Unexpectedly
entry.content:
Chromium renderers use a default play rate of 0.0 while the Media

Foundation Media Engine has a default play rate of 1.0. As a result of

this if a control calls StartPlayingFrom prior to calling

SetPlaybackRate the content would start rendering, which is unexpected

from the Chromium side.



(Note: the HTMLMediaElement has a default play rate of 1.0, but

there is some additional state management between the Element, the

web media player, and the pipeline which will limit setting this rate

on a renderer)



There is an additional corner case here where calling SetPlaybackRate

prior to the Media Foundation Media Engine finalizing topology load may

result in the default playback rate being applied. This variation is

also addressed here by updating the default rate when SetPlaybackRate

is called.



Bug: 1362316

entry.title: IDB: fix crash in cursor when execution context is disconnected.
entry.content:
Previously, some IDBCursor code checked the status of the

IDBDatabase which seems like it should handle the context destruction

case. However,



a) this check was not applied consistently

b) this check is not reliable

c) this check was broken



To address (a),



This change unifies the checks that various IDBCursor methods (IDL

implementations) apply before proceeding with the implementation.



To explain and address (b),



Since news of the destruction of an ExecutionContext is propagated

non-instaneously, it's possible for the ExecutionContext to be

destroyed but for `ContextDestroyed()` not to have been called yet

on any given `ContextLifecycleObserver()`. For this reason, it's

not safe to rely on secondary state such as the status of the

database connection to the browser process to indicate whether

the context has been destroyed. This change double checks

`IsContextDestroyed()` before allowing operations like `continue()`.



To explain and address (c),



The database check, where it was applied, had been broken by

crrev.com/f193122784d956cdd8feb which combined the IDBDatabase and

WebIDBDatabase. The WebIDBDatabase might have previously been null

when disconnected, but the IDBDatabase is never null, so null checks

(in IDBCursor and beyond) are replaced with a call to a new method

`IDBDatabase::IsConnectionOpen()` which checks the mojo connection.

The mojo connection automatically resets on context destruction.



Bug: 1514569, 1519989

entry.title: Remove destruction of the resource provider in CheckForGpuContextLost
entry.content:
When `CheckForGpuContextLost` is called, if it is detected that the GPU

process has crashed, the resource provider is destroyed. This seems to

be causing use-after-free issues since `CheckForGpuContextLost` is

called from `GetOrCreateResourceProvider`, resulting in unexpected uses

of a now null resource provider.



Since `CheckForGpuContextLost` also sets a flag to indicate that the

context has been lost and should be recovered, it is not necessary to

set the resource provider to nullptr at this point. Therefore, the

destruction of the resource provider has been removed.



Fixed: 1520316

entry.title: Extract LastWriterInfo logic out of ClipboardHostImpl
entry.content:
To evaluate Data Controls rules, enterprise code will need to be able

to check if the last seqno committed to the clipboard originated from

Chrome or not. This logic already exists internally in ClipboardHostImpl

and this CL simply extracts that logic to a file in content/public/

to be used in later CLs.



This CL also performs some cleanups:

- The raw pointer in the struct is replaced by a GlobalRenderFrameHostId

to avoid potential pointer issues later.

- The cleanup logic in ClipboardHostImpl's destructor is tweaked to

only clear the last writer if it corresponds to the ClipboardHostImpl

being destroyed.

entry.title: Handle index mismatch in TabWindowManager when one activity is finishing
entry.content:
It has been observed that sometimes due to back to back

ChromeTabbedActivity creation, TabWindowManager#requestSelector fails to

assign the requested index for the second launched activity because it

has already been assigned to an activity launched shortly before.



This CL adds a speculative fix to handle this index mismatch for when

the first launched activity is finishing during the assignments for the

second activity; in this case the following actions will be taken:



- Destroy the TabPersistentStore instance owned by the finishing

activity to avoid parallel disk updates while the second activity is

initializing.

- Clear the index/selector assignments of the finishing activity and

reassign the requested index to the second launched activity.



OBSOLETE_HISTOGRAM[Android.MultiWindowMode.AssertIndicesMatch]=Replaced by Android.MultiWindowMode.AssertIndicesMatch{ActivityIndexMismatchAssignmentState}

entry.title: Revert "Simplify MetricsHandler::HandleRecordInHistogram"
entry.content:
This reverts commit f1c852cdb5bda3002d3845cd71ed41ea49ea6a43.



Reason for revert: The CHECKs are catching real crashes. Will fix the real crashes then reland.



Original change's description:

> Simplify MetricsHandler::HandleRecordInHistogram

>

> This CL simplifies MetricsHandler::HandleRecordInHistogram used in

> WebUI.

>

> Previously, this function had a custom method of generating a histogram

> and deciding the histogram buckets. I found that to be not great,

> because:

> 1) It was specific to WebUI.

> 2) In practice, the bucket dividing code was never used, because every

> caller has a maximum of less than 100.

>

> This CL converts it to follow the semantics of

> base::UmaHistogramExactLinear. Every WebUI caller that I could find in

> the codebase would have no problem with this:

>

> https://source.chromium.org/search?q=metricsHandler:recordInHistogram%20-path:%5Egen%2F%20-path:%5Eout%2F

entry.title: Skip unwanted zeroconf scanner responses
entry.content:
Some scanners return zeroconf responses for multiple scanning protocols.

These are normally merged into a single scanner record before sending

them to the Scan app. However, in cases where one protocol is known to

provide a better experience than others for a particular device, it is

better to skip the unwanted zeroconf response(s) entirely.



This CL adds a mechanism to skip zeroconf scanner records before setting

them up and adds one initial case. It also makes the log messages more

consistent with the zeroconf printer detector.



Bug: b/288301496

Test: Run Scan app with XP-7100

Change-Id: I3cac848fd77df5876fb16dc38e3724efce2fe3f2

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5240045

Reviewed-by: Piotr Pawliczek

Commit-Queue: Benjamin Gordon

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1252730}

entry.title: Fix UaF in deferred spare renderer
entry.content:
If the spare renderer creation is deferred, the last recorded

BrowserContext in SpareRenderProcessHostManager might have been

destroyed before the spare renderer creation. Use a WeakPtr to

BrowserContext to avoid the potential user-after-free bug.

entry.title: [A11y] Better aria-owns validity check when repairing missing parent
entry.content:
Fix the new test by doing a complete validity check of a potential

aria-owns relation before creating child with the aria-owns parent

as its parent. It's possible to do a complete check, including a

check for cycles, because the validity check only requires

a child Node (does not require a candidate AXObject). The test had

failed before because one of the places where we checked for

aria-owns validity did not check for a cycle, due to that check

needing an AXObject.



The new Node-based validity check allows for improvements in other

places that used it after guessing that an aria-owns relation was

going to be good, and reversing it after finding out it was bad.

Now, the check can be done beforehand and there's nothing to "undo" --

we no longer need to create a candidate AXObject just to check whether

the aria-owns parent makes sense as a parent.



Fixed: 1518753, 1519090

Change-Id: I43764e32c44506383b7af37ab56e48d10e0bca74

entry.title: media: Disable hardware secure decryption for AMD Polaris devices
entry.content:
Disabled hardware secure decryption for AMD Polaris-architecture

devices because users may have poor playback experience by the high

chance of error due to its limitation where they can create

crypto-session instances only up to 4 at the same time. This

architecture-based GPUs have a higher error rate both in the

playback and CDM creation than the average of all AMD ones. The full

list of affected device IDs was directly collected from the AMD vendor.



By disabling the hardware secure decryption for these devices, we

expect to see some benefits:

- Improve the success rate (with slightly losing the device coverage)

- Avoid unnecessary investigation time on the reported issues caused by

the same limitation



To override if the system is affected/disabled by this change,

- Use `--disable_media_foundation_hardware_security=0` flag

- Alternatively, use `--override-hardware-secure-codecs-for-testing`

flag



Tested locally with and without including my test device in the

disabling list. Also verified passing

`--disable_media_foundation_hardware_security=0` flag neutralized

the GPU bug workaround feature when disabled.



For details, see http://shortn/_kt5Tuy5gdw



Bug: 1401061, 1383419, b/284154087, b/322405432

Change-Id: If3df6db846cff86a5ae4b1de17006880ac7e8e49

entry.title: documentScan: Create tokens in LorgnetteScannerManager
entry.content:
Currently, LorgnetteScannerManager::GetScannerInfoList returns raw SANE

connection strings. For chrome.documentScan, these are replaced with

anonymous tokens in DocumentScanAPIHandler before returning to a client.

The API handler has to be very conservative about invalidating tokens

because it doesn't have enough information to confirm when a given

connection string truly refers to the same device.



Instead, handle the token creation logic in LorgnetteScannerManager,

where more information about the state of the devices is available.

This will allow the API handler to be simplified by just tracking which

tokens have been issued to a given client. This will also ensure

consistency with future planned consumers of this functionality without

requiring them to also implement the same rules.



Bug: b/316152239

Change-Id: Iae8d5ffdf329b6a7ba0ef09b5af48d62a5f85d1d

entry.title: Wayland: fix positioning of menus with ChromeRefresh2023.
entry.content:
ChromeRefresh2023 added client-side decorations to menus resulting

them to be positioned by Wayland improperly. That is, Wayland

must know the visible area and the insets that are set via

xdg_surface::set_surface_geometry. Otherwise, the xdg_positioner

will position the window by its entire size (decorations + visible

area).



Prior to this CL, the geometry was correctly set only for a toplevel

window (insets passed from the BrowserDesktopWindowTreeHostLinux).



Given there is no browser frame for a menu, but rather a MenuHost

owns the Widget, which owns the window tree host and the platform

window, the MenuHost is notified about creation of a native widget

now and sets decoration insets if `SupportsClientFrameShadow` is

true (same condition that is used by the browser window). Those

insets are further used by WaylandPopup to set its underlying

`xdg_surface` geometry using those insets.



Bug: 1487137

Change-Id: I87779e57cc3da7af0cc3ffce58a8e40ed331910c

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5205030

Commit-Queue: Maksim Sisov

Reviewed-by: Scott Violet

Reviewed-by: Alexander Dunaev

entry.title: Update EG test util for non-disappearing snackbars
entry.content:
MDCSnackBar recently changed behavior: in the past, all snackbars

disappeared automatically after a delay. Now, snackbars with one or more

actions stay on screen. This is an accessibility improvement for people

with motor or cognitive impairment: it gives time to notice and interact

with the snackbar.



This CL updates the EG util that checked for a snackbar appearance and

disappearance. Now, the snackbar is tapped (on its label, to not trigger

the associated action).



Fixed: 1520513, 1519535
